content.text: Once upon a time, in a quiet village nestled between rolling green hills and a sparkling river, there lived a kind but very poor old man named Taro.
Though he had little, Taro was known far and wide for his generous heart.

Every evening, he would share his meager supper with any traveler who passed by his humble cottage, and he never turned away a creature in need—whether it was a lost kitten, a wounded sparrow, or a shivering fox.
One bitter winter’s night, as snowflakes danced like tiny silver stars from the sky, Taro heard a soft tapping at his door.
When he opened it, he found a great white crane, its feathers dusted with snow, standing weakly on one leg.
The crane’s dark eyes were filled with pain, and a thin arrow was lodged in its wing.
“Oh, poor thing!” Taro exclaimed, kneeling in the snow.
Gently, he lifted the crane into his arms and carried it inside.
He built up the fire in his hearth, then carefully removed the arrow and cleaned the wound with warm water and herbs.
For days, he nursed the crane back to health, feeding it rice and speaking to it in soothing tones.
At last, the crane’s wing healed, and it could stand tall once more.
One morning, the crane spread its wings and let out a joyful cry. Taro smiled.
“You’re well again, my friend,” he said.
“You must fly back to your family now.” But the crane did not leave.
Instead, it bowed its long neck and looked at Taro as if to say, I will not forget your kindness.
Days passed, and the crane stayed.
It would perch on the roof of Taro’s cottage in the mornings, watching over him as he tended his small garden.
In the evenings, it would stand by the fire, its feathers glowing in the golden light.
Taro grew fond of the crane, and though he was still poor, he no longer felt lonely.
One evening, as the first stars twinkled in the sky, the crane suddenly spoke in a voice as soft as falling snow.
“Taro,” it said, “you have shown me great kindness.
Now, I wish to repay you.” Before Taro could answer, the crane spread its wings and began to dance.
With each graceful step, its feathers shimmered and fell to the floor, transforming into threads of the purest silver and gold.
Taro watched in amazement as the crane wove the threads into the most beautiful cloth he had ever seen—silken and glowing, like moonlight on water.
When the dance was done, the crane bowed and presented the cloth to Taro.
“Take this to the market,” it said.
“Sell it, and you will never be poor again.”  The next morning, Taro wrapped the cloth carefully in a linen cloth and set off for the village.
The merchant at the market gasped when he saw the shimmering fabric.
“This is the work of the gods!” he cried.
He paid Taro a great sum of gold, more than the old man had ever dreamed of.
With the money, Taro bought warm clothes, food for the winter, and even gifts for the children of the village.
News of Taro’s fortune spread quickly, and soon, a greedy neighbor named Jiro came to visit.
“How did you come by such wealth?” he asked, his eyes narrow with suspicion.
Taro, who was honest to a fault, told him the whole story—the wounded crane, its healing, and the magical cloth.
Jiro’s eyes gleamed with greed.
“Bring me such a crane,” he demanded, “and I will nurse it back to health as you did.
Then I, too, shall have golden cloth!”  Taro shook his head. “It is not so simple, my friend.
The crane came to me because of my kindness, not because I sought reward.”  But Jiro would not listen.
That very night, he set out into the snow, searching for a crane.
At last, he found one—a beautiful bird with feathers like fresh snow.
Without hesitation, he shot an arrow into its wing, then carried it home, pretending to be gentle.
He cleaned the wound and fed the crane, but his heart was cold.
He did not speak kindly to the bird, nor did he truly care for it.
All he could think of was the golden cloth. When the crane’s wing healed, Jiro commanded it to dance.
“Make me cloth like Taro’s!” he barked. The crane looked at him with sad eyes, then spread its wings.
But this time, as it danced, its feathers did not turn to gold.
Instead, they fell to the floor as ordinary feathers, and the crane grew weaker with each step.
At last, it collapsed, its breath ragged. Jiro screamed in fury.
“You worthless bird!” he shouted, kicking at the feathers. But the crane did not move.
With a final, sorrowful cry, it closed its eyes and was still.
Heart pounding, Jiro realized what he had done.
He had been cruel and greedy, and now the crane was gone.
Ashamed and afraid, he fled his house, never to return.
Some say he wandered the land as a beggar, forever haunted by his selfishness.
Meanwhile, Taro’s crane had not returned to his cottage.
He searched for it every day, calling its name, but it was nowhere to be found.
Though he was sad, he knew he had done the right thing by helping the bird, and he lived the rest of his days with gratitude in his heart.
And so, the tale of the grateful crane reminds us that kindness is its own reward.
Those who give with an open heart will find that goodness always returns to them—like the gentle flutter of wings on a winter’s night.
